nodes.text: IoT-based smart home systems can simultaneously enhance residential energy efficiency and home security while enabling integration with smart city infrastructures
IoT architectures for smart homes comprise sensors, actuators, controllers, and communication protocols (ZigBee, Z-Wave, Wi-Fi, BLE, Thread) that enable real-time monitoring and automation

IoT-enabled energy management using real-time data, AI/ML, and device automation can reduce household energy consumption by up to approximately 30 percent and cut heating and cooling costs substantially
Security in IoT smart homes can be improved via end-to-end encryption, blockchain device authentication, and machine learning based intrusion detection systems to reduce breaches and detection time

There are significant challenges—device interoperability, high initial costs, scalability, fragmented security standards, and computational constraints of devices—that limit current IoT smart home deployment and benefits

System design uses sensors (motion, temperature, humidity, gas), actuators (relays, valves, motors), controllers (Raspberry Pi, Arduino) and communication networks to coordinate automation and edge computing
Edge computing and local AI on controllers reduce latency and improve responsiveness compared to cloud-only architectures

Evidence from case studies and reports: Nest thermostats reduce heating by 10-12% and cooling by 15%; a 2022 California study with 1000 smart thermostats saved 1.2 GWh in one year; smart lighting and EMS claim up to 30% household energy reduction
AI/ML roles include demand response, predictive maintenance, consumption forecasting and dashboards that provide actionable recommendations to reduce peak usage and extend equipment life

Evidence for security improvements: proper encryption reduces device compromise rates (Symantec report), blockchain can reduce IoT cyber risk estimates by up to 50%, and ML-based IDS reduce response times from hours to milliseconds
Real-time IDS and automated isolation of compromised devices allow systems to neutralize threats quickly and notify users, improving operational security

Interoperability and standardization gaps: proprietary protocols and device incompatibility cause about 60 percent of devices to experience compatibility issues, impeding integrated energy management and security

High initial deployment costs (typical household cost range cited around 1500 to 2000 USD) and limited computational capacity of many devices hinder adoption and the use of sophisticated security algorithms
Future trends such as 5G/6G, edge computing, AI, blockchain, quantum cryptography, and IoT-powered microgrids can address latency, scalability, security, and renewable integration challenges

Recommendation: Promote standardized protocols (Matter, Thread), regulatory frameworks, AI-driven optimization, decentralized energy solutions, and public-private partnerships to accelerate secure, interoperable, and cost-effective IoT smart home adoption
